title: The Human Factor (1979 film)
text:
The Human Factor is a 1979 British <a href="neo%20noir">neo noir</a> <a href="thriller%20film">thriller film</a> directed and produced by <a href="Otto%20Preminger">Otto Preminger</a> and starring <a href="Richard%20Attenborough">Richard Attenborough</a>, <a href="Nicol%20Williamson">Nicol Williamson</a>, <a href="Derek%20Jacobi">Derek Jacobi</a> and <a href="John%20Gielgud">John Gielgud</a>. It is based on the 1978 novel "<a href="The%20Human%20Factor%20%28novel%29">The Human Factor</a>" by <a href="Graham%20Greene">Graham Greene</a>, with the screenplay written by <a href="Tom%20Stoppard">Tom Stoppard</a>. It examines British espionage, and the West's relationship with apartheid South Africa.
This was Preminger's last film.
Plot.
Maurice Castle (<a href="Nicol%20Williamson">Nicol Williamson</a>) is a mid-level bureaucrat in <a href="MI6">MI6</a> whose life seems unremarkable, apart from the fact that he has an African wife, Sarah (<a href="Iman%20%28model%29">Iman</a>), and son, Sam (Gary Forbes). The company regime, represented by Dr. Percival (<a href="Robert%20Morley">Robert Morley</a>), an expert in assassinations and biological toxins, and <a href="%C3%A9minence%20grise">éminence grise</a> Sir John Hargreaves (<a href="Richard%20Vernon">Richard Vernon</a>), advise newly appointed security chief Daintry (<a href="Richard%20Attenborough">Richard Attenborough</a>) that they believe they have a leak in Castle's department. The duo determine the mole must be quietly killed, rather than be allowed publicity in a trial or a flight to Moscow. They quickly decide the most likely candidate for the traitor is Arthur Davis (<a href="Derek%20Jacobi">Derek Jacobi</a>), Castle's <a href="red%20brick%20university">redbrick</a>-educated <a href="playboy%20%28lifestyle%29">playboy</a> office partner.
Castle is actually the <a href="mole%20%28espionage%29">mole</a>, but the information he leaks is mostly unimportant. He became involved in leaking to the Soviets when he was an MI6 agent in <a href="apartheid">apartheid</a> South Africa, seven years earlier: he met and fell in love with Sarah; when their affair was discovered by the authorities, Castle was thrown out of the country, and Sarah was smuggled out with the help of Matthew Connolly (<a href="Tony%20Vogel">Tony Vogel</a>), whose Communist network Castle was originally assigned to spy upon. Ever since, Castle has been repaying the favor by passing information on via a contact in London. However, Castle is not a communist. His only interest is in his wife and son, who are ultimately left in London — where they remain separated from him.
Production.
The film was shot in <a href="Kenya">Kenya</a> and at <a href="Shepperton%20Studios">Shepperton</a> and <a href="Pinewood%20Studios">Pinewood Studios</a> near <a href="London">London</a> as well as on location at <a href="Berkhamsted">Berkhamsted</a>. As with the book, much of the theme about alleged <a href="treason">treason</a> and suspicion is based on the defection of <a href="Kim%20Philby">Kim Philby</a>, a friend of Graham Greene, to the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviets</a>. The film also included <a href="Iman%20%28model%29">Iman</a>, who was working as a model before she began to work in films.
Preminger had trouble securing funding for the film and had to partially fund it with his own money. According to "<a href="The%20Daily%20Telegraph">The Daily Telegraph</a>" obituary of casting director <a href="Rose%20Tobias%20Shaw">Rose Tobias Shaw</a>, Preminger wanted to cast the novelist <a href="Jeffrey%20Archer">Jeffrey Archer</a> in the role eventually played by Nicol Williamson. Archer, much shorter than Iman, failed his audition.
Release.
The film was the first acquisition by <a href="Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer">Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer</a> in six years for distribution in the United States and Canada, through United Artists. The film was released for an <a href="Academy%20Awards">Academy Awards</a> qualifying run in <a href="Los%20Angeles">Los Angeles</a>, as well in <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a>.
